pullRequest.body:
feat: change mostly in MeasureTheory.Function.TendstoInMeasure
Two new features:
1) Limits in Measure are ae unique
2) Convergence in Measure is equivalent to the proof that every subsequence has a further subsequence which converges (back-direction is new)


---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I think the conflict was spurious, in the sense that git's default algorithm could solve this on its own. (Hence, I would not get any conflicts in VS Code.) In this case, I think you can click on the "merge" button directly. (Or, if you work from the terminal, typing `git merge master` will already succeed, you can confirm the commit message and push.)

Many thanks, that helped a lot!
Did you make changes locally? I think you might have forgotten to push.

Yes, indeed. Now it is pushed...
Is this ready to be reviewed again? If so, please remove the awaiting-author label and readd the awaiting-review label.

> Is this ready to be reviewed again? If so, please remove the awaiting-author label and readd the awaiting-review label.

Thanks, I am still new to making PRs...
Thanks for all the comments, which helped me to learn several things (in particular streamlining some proofs).

Sorry that I apparently have not addressed all issues from the last round, since I did my best to do so. Usually, I respond, but nevertheless click on "resolve", since the page becomes too long otherwise. Is this ok?

If you apply a suggestion and then resolve, it's fine, and you don't need to respond to indicate that you applied it because I can see it in the code. On the other hand, there are some suggestions which you only applied partially, and I don't know if it is because you missed them or because you preferred not to apply them. So I would say that the best way to proceed is to make sure you applied the whole suggestion before resolving, and if you had a good reason not too, then indicate why and keep it unresolved so I can see it easily.
Of course there are many comments and it is easy to oversee some, especially when there are many changes in one suggestion.
If a code suggestion seems reasonable to you, you can use the "Commit suggestion" button to automatically commit the change to the branch (make sure to refresh your local branch if you do that). This avoids forgetting some changes.
Please fix the build before removing the awaiting-author label.
Sorry, now it builds... (Forgot to save my file...)
A few more comments, we're almost there!
Thank you for your work! These are mostly remarks about the style, to make your code more readable and mathlib friendly.

Here comes a second wave! More little details about the shape of the code. Some lemmas are unnecessary I think, I put advices to shorten many proofs. In particular the proof of `exists_seq_tendstoInMeasure_atTop_iff` can be made much shorter. I tried to explain in some places, but please do not hesitate to ask if something is not clear, e.g. why one way would be better than another, or if you do not understand the syntax of some tactics.

More remarks on the style, more shortcuts. I noticed that there are some stuff I had indicated last time which you did not take into account. When you decide not to apply a suggestion, can you please indicate it, and potentially explain why? (readability etc.) Some of them are merely suggestions and up to your preference, but I don't know if you missed them or if you just decided not to apply them. I am aware that there are a lot of remarks and it takes time to go through it, but if you don't settle all the suggestions before removing the awaiting author label it will only slow down he process even more.
Also note that you have a build error, please make sure to fix it before removing awaiting author.
A few more comments, we're almost there!

```suggestion
  filter_upwards [hg, hh] with ω hg1 hh1 using tendsto_nhds_unique hg1 hh1
```
Also the spelling for ae convergence is `tendsto_ae` so I would change the name of this lemma to `tendsto_ae_unique`
Thanks, done.
Could you use `𝓝` instead of `nhds` (obtained by typing \nhds) here and elsewhere? Also, your assumption `hh` is split among two lines, while it would fit on one line.

```suggestion
    TendstoInMeasure μ f l g ↔ TendstoInMeasure' μ f l g := by
```
Intendation in theorem statements should be 4 spaces.

```suggestion
lemma sub_TendstoInMeasure' [Dist E] {f : ι → α → E}  {g : α → E} {u v : Filter ι} (huv : v ≤ u)
```
Can you see if you can move this to either where `tendsto_nhds_unique` is or where the `ae` filter is defined?
I agree that it is/was not in a good place. I think `MeasureTheory.Measure.Function.AEEqFun.lean` is a good place and I will put it there.
I'm not convinced that this definition is useful. Can you explain a bit more why it is needed?

It boils down to having a coercion `NNRead.toReal` but not a coercion `ENNReal.toReal`. Since the former exists, it is possible to compute stuff more easily when using `TendstoInMeasure'` rather than `TendstoInMeasure`. Of course there are other ways to avoid having this definition, but ir really helped me computing things faster.

I think rather than making a new definition, it is better to replace the right hand side of `TendstoInMeasure_of_FiniteMeasure` by ` ∀ ε, 0 < ε → Tendsto (ENNReal.toNNReal ∘ (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) }))) l (𝓝 0)`
This is also a good idea. I not deleted the definition and followed the suggestion.


```suggestion
    (hh : ∀ᵐ ω ∂μ, Tendsto (fun i => f i ω) l (𝓝 (h ω))) : g =ᵐ[μ] h := by
```

Yes, it does!

```suggestion
      (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) }).toNNReal) l (𝓝 0) := by
```

Ok, changed.
Changed.

Yes, I removed it. The weaker version was part of the file before my PR.

```suggestion
    ∃ (ns : ℕ → ι) (_ : Tendsto ns atTop u), ∀ᵐ x ∂μ, Tendsto (fun i => f (ns i) x) atTop (𝓝 (g x)) := by
```

Yes, you are right, this now also works. Added...

```suggestion
theorem tendstoInMeasure_iff_tendsto_toNNReal [Dist E] {_ : MeasurableSpace α} {μ : Measure α}
```
The first character of a theorem should not be capitalized (unless its a part of the dot notation). See [here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html) for more details. Please change this and all the declarations below.

More specifically: 
Terms of Props (e.g. proofs, theorem names) use `snake_case` &
When something named with `UpperCamelCase` is part of something named with snake_case, it is referenced in `lowerCamelCase`.
Thanks for pointing this out. I hope I have caught all occurrencies which disagreed with the convention.

```suggestion
  convergence in measure is equivalent to the fact that every subsequence has another subsequence
  that converges almost surely.
```
I don't quite understand this name. I don't see an at top filter here. Maybe the name `TendstoInMeasure.comp_of_tendsto` is a better name?

```suggestion
    TendstoInMeasure μ (f ∘ ns) v g :=
```

```suggestion
/- Convergence in measure is equivalent to every subsequence has another subsequence
```

```suggestion
theorem TendstoInMeasure.ae_eq' (hg : TendstoInMeasure μ f atTop g)
```
The name `limitInMeasure` is not used anywhere else so we should not use it. Same with below

```suggestion
    Tendsto (ENNReal.toNNReal ∘ f ) u (𝓝 (a.toNNReal)) := by
```
This name seems weird to me. Maybe `coe_comp_toNNReal_comp` is better?
Ok, done.

Why did you give a name to the measurable space instance and did not put it inside `[...]`? You can reuse the variables already existing in the file instead of introducing new ones.
```suggestion
theorem tendsto_ae_unique {ι : Type*} [T2Space β] {g h : α → β} {f : ι → α → β}
    {l : Filter ι} [l.NeBot]
    (hg : ∀ᵐ ω ∂μ, Tendsto (fun i => f i ω) l (𝓝 (g ω)))
    (hh : ∀ᵐ ω ∂μ, Tendsto (fun i => f i ω) l (𝓝 (h ω))) : g =ᵐ[μ] h := by
```
Yes, this is much better.

You can reuse already existing variable. Here is a nicer header I think:
```suggestion
theorem tendstoInMeasure_iff_tendsto_toNNReal [Dist E] [IsFiniteMeasure μ] {f : ι → α → E}
    {l : Filter ι} {g : α → E} : TendstoInMeasure μ f l g ↔
      ∀ ε > 0, Tendsto (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) }).toNNReal) l (𝓝 0) := by
```
Thanks, this is shorter indeed.

```suggestion
  have hfin ε i : μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) } ≠ ⊤ := measure_ne_top _ _
```

```suggestion
  · intro h ε hε
```
I streamlined the code by using `refine ⟨fun h ε hε ↦ ?_, fun h ε hε ↦ ?_⟩`.

```suggestion
    have hf : (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) }).toNNReal) =
        ENNReal.toNNReal ∘ (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) })) := rfl
```
Done.

```suggestion
    rw [ENNReal.tendsto_toNNReal_iff ENNReal.zero_ne_top (hfin ε)]
```
Done.

```suggestion
lemma TendstoInMeasure.mono [Dist E] {f : ι → α → E} {g : α → E} {u v : Filter ι} (huv : v ≤ u)
    (hg : TendstoInMeasure μ f u g) : TendstoInMeasure μ f v g :=
```
Done.

```suggestion
lemma TendstoInMeasure.subseq [Dist E] {f : ℕ → α → E} {g : α → E} {ns : ℕ → ℕ}
    (hns : StrictMono ns) (hg : TendstoInMeasure μ f atTop g) :
```
Done.

```suggestion
lemma TendstoInMeasure.subseq' [Dist E] {f : ι → α → E} {g : α → E} {u : Filter ι}
    {v : Filter κ} {ns : κ → ι} (hns : Tendsto ns v u) (hg : TendstoInMeasure μ f u g) :
```
Done.

```suggestion
    TendstoInMeasure μ (f ∘ ns) atTop g :=
  fun ε hε => (hg ε hε).comp hns.tendsto_atTop
```
Done.

```suggestion
    TendstoInMeasure μ (f ∘ ns) v g :=
  fun ε hε => (hg ε hε).comp hns
```
Done.

I think this is nicer.
```suggestion
    ∃ ns : ℕ → ι, Tendsto ns atTop u ∧ TendstoInMeasure μ (fun n => f (ns n)) atTop g := by
```
Done, changed the next lemma accordingly.

This is nicer.
```suggestion
    ∃ ns : ℕ → ι, Tendsto ns atTop u ∧ ∀ᵐ x ∂μ, Tendsto (fun i => f (ns i) x) atTop (𝓝 (g x)) := by
  obtain ⟨ms, hms1, hms2⟩ := hfg.exists_seq_tendstoInMeasure_atTop
  obtain ⟨ns, hns1, hns2⟩ := hms2.exists_seq_tendsto_ae
  exact ⟨ms ∘ ns, hms1.comp hns1.tendsto_atTop, hns2⟩
```
Yes, it is. Done.

This lemma is really not a good lemma for Mathlib. It is highly specific and has nothing to do convergence in measure. Sometimes you need something very specific and you might make it `private`, but in this case you can replace the use of your lemma with very few lines, I'll show you below. So I think you should remove it.
This is the same as `TendstoInMeasure.subseq'`.
True. Deleted.
This lemma is also too specific, the argument should be done directly in the proof.

Easier to read I think:
```suggestion
theorem exists_seq_tendstoInMeasure_atTop_iff [IsFiniteMeasure μ]
    {f : ℕ → α → E} (hf : ∀ (n : ℕ), AEStronglyMeasurable (f n) μ) {g : α → E} :
    (TendstoInMeasure μ f atTop g) ↔
      ∀ ns : ℕ → ℕ, StrictMono ns → ∃ ns' : ℕ → ℕ, StrictMono ns' ∧
        ∀ᵐ (ω : α) ∂μ, Tendsto (fun i ↦ f (ns (ns' i)) ω) atTop (𝓝 (g ω)) := by
```
Ok, done.

This can be done in one line, provided that you move the above `rewrite below`:
```suggestion
  · exact fun hfg _ hns ↦ (hfg.subseq hns).exists_seq_tendsto_ae
```

Here you can `push_neg` in `h1` too and automatically get `ε`.
```suggestion
    push_neg at *
    obtain ⟨ε, hε, h2⟩ := h1
```

Here is a way to replace your lemma:
```suggestion
    obtain ⟨δ, ns, hδ, hns, h3⟩ : ∃ (δ : ℝ≥0) (ns : ℕ → ℕ), 0 < δ ∧ StrictMono ns ∧
        ∀ n, δ ≤ (μ {x | ε ≤ dist (f (ns n) x) (g x)}).toNNReal := by
      obtain ⟨s, hs, h4⟩ := not_tendsto_iff_exists_frequently_nmem.1 h2
      obtain ⟨δ, hδ, h5⟩ := NNReal.nhds_zero_basis.mem_iff.1 hs
      obtain ⟨ns, hns, h6⟩ := extraction_of_frequently_atTop h4
      exact ⟨δ, ns, hδ, hns, fun n ↦ Set.not_mem_Iio.1 (Set.not_mem_subset h5 (h6 n))⟩
```

You can do this in one line with `refine`. `refine` is very useful, it allows you to write the skeleton of the proof and creating a goal for each `?_` you write.
```suggestion
    refine ⟨ns, hns, fun ns' _ ↦ ?_⟩
```

h4 is unnecessary here.
```suggestion
    have h8 := tendstoInMeasure_of_tendsto_ae (fun _ ↦ hf _) h6
```

A bit shorter (`obtain` should only be used when you want to destruct the statement, typically if there is an `∃` or an `∧`) :
```suggestion
    have h7 n := h5 (ns' n)
```
This is not needed.

This finishes the proof:
```suggestion
    exact lt_irrefl _ (lt_of_le_of_lt (ge_of_tendsto' (h5 ε hε) h6) hδ)
```
You can remove that.
It is unnecessary to have this lemma when the general version is easily deduced, just put the proof in the general case directly.

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨ns, h1, h1'⟩ := hg.exists_seq_tendstoInMeasure_atTop
```

```suggestion
  exact ae_unique_of_tendstoInMeasure' h1' (hh.subseq' h1)
```

A better name maybe. This does not involve the identity so I don't think `id` should appear.
```suggestion
lemma tendsto_coe_toNNReal {a : ℝ≥0∞} (ha : a ≠ ⊤) : Tendsto (↑) (𝓝 a.toNNReal) (𝓝 a) := by
  nth_rewrite 2 [← coe_toNNReal ha]
  exact continuous_coe.tendsto _
```

```suggestion
    Tendsto (ENNReal.toNNReal ∘ f) u (𝓝 (a.toNNReal)) := by
```

`refine` is great! Do not hesitate to use dot notation as frequently as possible. If a theorem starts with `Filter.Tendsto` and takes an argument `Filter.Tendsto _ _ _` you can replace `Filter.Tendsto` with your argument in the name of the lemma, making it shorter.
```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun h => (ENNReal.tendsto_toNNReal ha).comp h, fun h => ?_⟩
```

```suggestion
    (hf : ∀ x, f x ≠ ∞) : Tendsto f u (𝓝 a) ↔ Tendsto (ENNReal.toNNReal ∘ f) u (𝓝 a) := by
```
I am not sure this lemma is very useful, although I would like someone else's opinion.

Unless we use them in the proof we don't give names to typeclass argument. Also the `MeasureTheory` prefix is unnecessary.
```suggestion
    [IsFiniteMeasure μ] {f : ι → α → E} {l : Filter ι} {g : α → E} :
```

Here you have an iff statement which does not fit in the line. I think the first thing to try is to write each part of the iff on a line each. Here it is possible, so I think it's easier to read.
```suggestion
    TendstoInMeasure μ f l g ↔
    ∀ ε, 0 < ε → Tendsto (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) }).toNNReal) l (𝓝 0) := by
```

When writing a `have` statement you should indent the statement with four spaces (two tabs), as it is done for the main statement. Also, skipping lines just after `fun i =>` feels weird to me, it seems like a cut inside a formula. I think this reads better:
```suggestion
  · have hf : (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) }).toNNReal) =
        ENNReal.toNNReal ∘ (fun i => (μ { x | ε ≤ dist (f i x) (g x) })) := rfl
```

I don't think we want the `subseq` statement, as it is an immediate consequence of the `subseq'` one. I think you should only keep the `subseq'` and rename it maybe `TendstoInMeasure.comp` as it is not about subsequences.
You didn't do the renaming.

```suggestion
/-- `TendstoInMeasure` is equivalent to every subsequence having another subsequence
```
For example here you changed the "has" but you did not remove the whitespace and add the "\`" around `TendstoInMeasure`.
You did not add the backticks around `TendstoInMeasure`. They allow the name to be displayed code-style in the doc.

You can just `push_neg` here.
```suggestion
  push_neg at *
```

You can combine those with `by_contra!`, which use `by_contra` and automatically applies `push_neg` at the new hypothesis.
```suggestion
  by_contra! h6
```

Nicer I think:
```suggestion
  obtain h7 := tendstoInMeasure_iff_tendsto_toNNReal.mp <|
    tendstoInMeasure_of_tendsto_ae (fun n ↦ hf _) h6
```

You can just end the proof with this.
```suggestion
  exact lt_irrefl _ (lt_of_le_of_lt (ge_of_tendsto' (h7 ε hε) (fun n ↦ h3 _)) hδ)
```

```suggestion
/-- The limit in measure is ae unique. -/
```
You forgot the full stop at the end.

Following the convention:
```suggestion
theorem tendstoInMeasure_ae_unique {g h : α → E} {f : ι → α → E} {u : Filter ι} [NeBot u]
```

pullRequest.title: feat(MeasureTheory): TendstoInMeasure gives ae unique limits; TendstoInMeasure equivalent to subsequences converging ae

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).

Can you merge master and resolve the merge conflict?

> Can you merge master and resolve the merge conflict?

I would really like to do that. However, I cannot see the merge conflict in my local vscode, so I need to find out what the conflict is...

> > Can you merge master and resolve the merge conflict?
> 
> I would really like to do that. However, I cannot see the merge conflict in my local vscode, so I need to find out what the conflict is...

I've taken the liberty to just merge master - let me know if that was premature and I can revert this!

I think the conflict was spurious, in the sense that git's default algorithm could solve this on its own. (Hence, I would not get any conflicts in VS Code.) In this case, I think you can click on the "merge" button directly. (Or, if you work from the terminal, typing `git merge master` will already succeed, you can confirm the commit message and push.)

> > > Can you merge master and resolve the merge conflict?
> >

>

In this case, I think you can click on the "merge" button directly. (Or, if you work from the terminal, typing `git merge master` will already succeed, you can confirm the commit message and push.)

Many thanks, that helped a lot!
Did you make changes locally? I think you might have forgotten to push.

> Did you make changes locally? I think you might have forgotten to push.

Yes, indeed. Now it is pushed...
Is this ready to be reviewed again? If so, please remove the awaiting-author label and readd the awaiting-review label.

> Is this ready to be reviewed again? If so, please remove the awaiting-author label and readd the awaiting-review label.

Thanks, I am still new to making PRs...
Thank you for your work! These are mostly remarks about the style, to make your code more readable and mathlib friendly.

Here comes a second wave! More little details about the shape of the code. Some lemmas are unnecessary I think, I put advices to shorten many proofs. In particular the proof of `exists_seq_tendstoInMeasure_atTop_iff` can be made much shorter. I tried to explain in some places, but please do not hesitate to ask if something is not clear, e.g. why one way would be better than another, or if you do not understand the syntax of some tactics.
Thanks for all the comments, which helped me to learn several things (in particular streamlining some proofs).

More remarks on the style, more shortcuts. I noticed that there are some stuff I had indicated last time which you did not take into account. When you decide not to apply a suggestion, can you please indicate it, and potentially explain why? (readability etc.) Some of them are merely suggestions and up to your preference, but I don't know if you missed them or if you just decided not to apply them. I am aware that there are a lot of remarks and it takes time to go through it, but if you don't settle all the suggestions before removing the awaiting author label it will only slow down he process even more.
Also note that you have a build error, please make sure to fix it before removing awaiting author.

Sorry that I apparently have not addressed all issues from the last round, since I did my best to do so. Usually, I respond, but nevertheless click on "resolve", since the page becomes too long otherwise. Is this ok?

If you apply a suggestion and then resolve, it's fine, and you don't need to respond to indicate that you applied it because I can see it in the code. On the other hand, there are some suggestions which you only applied partially, and I don't know if it is because you missed them or because you preferred not to apply them. So I would say that the best way to proceed is to make sure you applied the whole suggestion before resolving, and if you had a good reason not too, then indicate why and keep it unresolved so I can see it easily.
Of course there are many comments and it is easy to oversee some, especially when there are many changes in one suggestion.
If a code suggestion seems reasonable to you, you can use the "Commit suggestion" button to automatically commit the change to the branch (make sure to refresh your local branch if you do that). This avoids forgetting some changes.
Please fix the build before removing the awaiting-author label.
Sorry, now it builds... (Forgot to save my file...)
A few more comments, we're almost there!
